string.text: It seems you needed me for something?
Marked One... You are one of those. You are needed by the enlightened. Accept the appointment and fulfill what is prescribed, as we all do!
Hold on, hold on! What’s going on here? What appointment? What are you talking about? I didn’t ask for any appointment. I just need to find out a couple of things, that’s all.

There is a message. There was. From the One That Is. The one who bears the Mark will come. Will be able to receive what he desires. And will bring understanding. It is necessary to guide... There is no unity at this moment of the flow of time. A transponder is needed. You will be able to make it. Then there will be unity. There will be replenishment. There will be direction... You, Marked One... Take the seed. Carry it to the place. Leave it. It will sprout. Then there will be unity and... A reward.
What “seed”? What “place”? What “reward”? What is all this? Why?
The seed. His. It will give the possibility of uniting minds. If it is sown at the points... The right ones...
Then why don’t you “sow” it here yourselves? And in general, you should do it yourselves. Your seeds, you sow them.
Not here. The seed is needed for Him at the points of connection with Him. It awaits you, but there is only one path to Him.
Wait, wait... Brrr! “It” is waiting for me? I actually wanted to find out how I can get past that barrier that won’t let me go any further... There, to the station.

Yes. It has been waiting for a long time. You are on the path of understanding... There was a seed, It sprouted in the Foggy Thicket... It received energy... But one is not enough... It needs more. Now it needs more... Those like you can. You do not need His attention, as we do. But you also bear His seal, It will let you pass. You are Marked One, It will let you pass.
So it is a “seal” after all?.. But I don’t feel any seal. Maybe there is nothing at all, and all of this is just... a coincidence? Absurdity?
You were marked by Him. Now I do not see His sign... But It remembers and will let you pass.
And why would It let me pass? To brand me again?
You want to know yourself. Only It will tell the truth. You will understand everything with Him. Who you truly are. Do not waste time. Strive toward Him.

Alright... Stranger things have happened. If there’s no other way to learn that truth, but there’s a chance to understand something by doing this... What kind of seeds are these and where do I plant them?
Places of energy. Of flows. Exit points... Of His shoots. You call these places “Matrices”.
Those are anomalies, right... And anyway, it still depends where to take them. I haven’t decided yet.

You humans say “Ivankovsky District Center”, there. You will be able to. Leave the seed... And you say “Tesla”. There... And you say “Radar”. Leave it. And plant it... The seed is alive. It will not die. In the right place it will sprout... At the right time. Do not wait. Time itself will come.
Oh, damn... I don’t know... I’ll think about it some more. \nAnd this... if I lose it, or it gets stolen, or I sell it — you never know, things happen — then what? Come back to you again?
It must not be lost... Do what must be done. There will be no others.
Everything’s so complicated with you... Why does “it” give so few seeds? Aren’t you afraid to part with such a rarity?
Not few... But by your temporal measures the process is long. In this span of time — there are none. The seed always exists. It will not be exhausted. But later. Much later.
Yeah, “it” has nowhere to hurry. It has eternity ahead... Alright, but if I do plant your seeds, then what? Look for you here again?
I will summon you when I understand that It has accepted the seed. Return and you will receive what is important. That with which you will be able to reach Him...
You could’ve started with that. Instead it’s him, from him, yours — damn it... My head’s spinning with you.
Take it and go. Do not waste time.
Your seeds sure are heavy...
So how’s Ivar doing?
And what about him? Looks like your Ivar is feeling better.
Why “my” Ivar?
Well, you’re always fussing over him. The Doctor said he’ll live.
Yeah... So the Doctor came by?
Yes. Didn’t stay long at all and left right away. Why he hides from people is unclear... Didn’t you run into him here?
Not here.

He came to take a look at Ivar. Injected him with something and left. Said there was nothing more to be done. Said these are consequences of radiation. Some kind of... local cerebral circulation disorder. Like a microstroke, basically. But he should gradually recover on his own, since he wasn’t crippled right away. Just shouldn’t strain himself mentally for now. And what is there for him to strain himself with... He just sits there and sits.
That’s already good. And where did the Doctor go?

How should I know? Hiding somewhere as usual. I heard through the grapevine, just between us, that he was hanging around Borov’s lot for a while. Either laying low with them or something else... Looks like he crossed someone or learned something he wasn’t supposed to. So he didn’t stick around here, left in a hurry.
With Borov’s people? Seriously? Did you make that up yourself?
Alright, I said it, you forgot it. Rumors, you know, don’t just appear out of nowhere.
Nonsense... And even if he was with them, so what? A doctor is a doctor — help without borders, so to speak.
Strelok's Notes

... 
 
 Well then, as for the so-called “monolith”, or as they have now begun to write in monographs — the Monolith — what would you say about it? What is its role in all of this? 
 
 There are many hypotheses, but given the current circumstances, the most reasonable one to me seems to be the following: 
 The Monolith absorbs hundreds of human psi-images, essentially feeds on them, replenishing its psi-energy. These include everyone who was in that area at the moment of the Monolith’s emergence about a hundred years ago, as well as those who somehow end up within this field even now — even though unprecedented protective measures have since been adopted, there are more and more “holes” leading there... Are you familiar with the theory of teleportation? 
 
 Well... briefly. Let’s not dwell on it. 
 
 So then. Those whom the Monolith has absorbed do not return — they become nobody, they are gone — and this is where the zombified come from. Their psycho-images were absorbed by the Monolith and it emptied their, uh... soul... far too strongly. 
 
 “Absorbed”? “Emptied the soul”. Isn’t that a bit... unscientific for a hypothesis of this level? 
 
 But somehow one has to explain to the layman, in imagery familiar to him, what “the superposition of a consciousness matrix” actually is. 
 
 Alright. Let’s go with that. But then what exactly is the Monolith itself? Some specific object? 
 
 It can hardly be classified as a material object. The Monolith does not need our physical universe, any material things, bodies, or space. Whatever it may be there, it requires a psychic universe — or, to put it more simply — mental images, everything on that kind of subtle level. Whether it feeds on this or exists within this “field” is still unclear; it remains a mystery even after so many years of study. 
 And since the Monolith itself is considered a non-material object — with only a certain visible projection of it being material, located in some kind of sarcophagus, not the Monolith itself as such — it essentially acts like an informational virus. 
 
 Wait, wait... Why did you decide that it is non-material? Why not simply assume that it is some kind of meteorite? There were such hypotheses as well. 
 
 This is one of the core postulates based on Professor Sokov’s “theory of the collision of worlds”. And at present, this is the most reasonable theory. The meteorite hypothesis collapsed a very long time ago. It is now generally accepted that the Monolith is the result of a “collision”, a “contact” of worlds, and similar terms. But nothing from “that world” — what we would call the antimatter world — can appear materially in this one. Otherwise, annihilation would be inevitable. But since it did not occur and we still exist, we cannot speak of materiality, though we can explain the collision in terms of information, the noosphere, if you will... Do you understand me? 
 
 With difficulty. But I’m trying. Let’s go back one step. 
 
 Yes. Alright. So, the Monolith, as a kind of informational virus, infects at the level of the mind. It changes not the structure of the brain as a physical object, but the minds of people. Roughly speaking, it replaces part of consciousness. It absorbs what exists, and inserts its own in the vacated space. A simple, clear analogy would be a computer virus. 
 
 We’ll take a short break... We’ve received several calls. 
 
 ...

... 
 
 How is this “expansion” even possible? After all, you yourself spoke of the object’s non-material nature. 
 
 Quite right. But how are we to explain its behavior in terms of our laws of physics? It is unknown what exists there, in the other universe of the Monolith, but in ours — the one it entered — the law of conservation of energy and the laws of thermodynamics apply. Therefore, it simply has to survive in our world somehow, as if it were a living object — to “grow”, to expand, to seize new territories, new sources of nourishment. Otherwise, inevitable entropy and death. In this world, at least. 
 
 Alright. Let us assume that, but earlier we spoke about a certain field of “powerlessness”. 
 
 Yes, yes. A little more on that. Then it turns out that this field of “apathy”, or rather “powerlessness”, as you put it, is precisely the result of the Monolith’s influence. The result of its “vital activity” in this world. It draws masses of people toward itself, infects them — that is, introduces a part of itself into their consciousness, replaces it with a virus, and so on — and then releases them. That is, it ceases that very “call” we spoke of. This is how the Monolith expands its sphere of influence, grows — for it has neither hands, nor legs, nor a body, yet it must somehow survive, having entered this world... You do understand that this is merely an abstract model? 
 
 Yes. I understand. 
 
 By the force of its influence, it encourages more and more people to strive toward its sphere of influence. This is its “food source”. That is why it induces illusions. And for some reason everyone “wants” to come closer to it, despite having no idea what is there — yet everyone shares the same thought: that it is good there, whatever it may be. 
 But this is not enough for it. The Monolith “throws out” traps, lures — the so-called artifacts — for the sake of which people not yet subject to the influence of the “call” may strive toward it. And the number of these “toys”, by which I mean the variety of types, already defies analysis. 
 It projects the illusion of some endless, free happiness somewhere nearby, close to it. And then it plunges people into apathy and, having “fed”, releases them beyond the perimeter with an already replaced consciousness. That is, it changes the polarity of the field from “come to me, here happiness is free” to “leave this place, there is only disappointment here”. 
 
 I’m afraid not everyone will be able to digest this. It’s like with the theory of relativity. It seems clear when explained on one’s fingers, but once you go into the details... 
 
 Naturally. The complete theory is far more complex, but I am explaining it to you precisely “on one’s fingers”. Otherwise we would stray into such depths that we would not have enough time for any conversation at all. Its format is limited as it is... 
 
 ...

... 
 
 Let’s talk a bit more about the “fragment”, and then it will be time for us to wrap up... 
 
 As I already said, the “fragment” is not a material stone, not a special artifact — it is something mental. It is that very virus which the carriers are meant to carry beyond the limits of the restricted territory and allow the Monolith to “grow”. 
 
 But how do they understand that they have a “fragment”? After all, everyone who had it speaks specifically of a material object. 
 
 No. All those who “had” it, had it as an illusion. They, roughly speaking, lost their minds, possessing such a mental image — a replica of the little Monolith. 
 And further, when they leave the sphere of its influence, all this madness does not go anywhere in any degree — it is inherited and grows progressively. Which is exactly what we are now observing everywhere. People are “growing stupider” right before our eyes. Universally. 
 And there you have the answer to how the Monolith, not being a living or material object of our world, nevertheless captures this world. This is the true “expansion of the Zone” with which we began our conversation. It is not territorial expansion at all. 
 
 Do you believe we can no longer stop this? This, how should I put it, “seizure of minds”. 
 
 It is hard to say. The rate of progression of mental disorders that we are observing inspires no optimism whatsoever. In essence, humanity as a species is degenerating. And the cause of it all, as the majority of scientists now believe, is that very initial virus introduced about a hundred years ago. This is a turning point in the history of mankind... 
 
 ...

... 
 
 Right, that’s exactly what I wanted to ask about — the so-called guardians of the Monolith. What kind of people are they? 
 
 That’s precisely what I’m telling you: the Monolithians are not quite human. Their consciousness has been restructured by the Monolith according to a special “program”, meaning they perform a certain controlling function and act as living receptors of the Monolith — through which it “sees”, “hears”, and “perceives” this world that is alien to it. They have a kind of mental connection with the Monolith. And some of them no longer even need to speak. 
 
 So these are the very same “zombies”? 
 
 No, not at all. They are not mindless zombies — “drained souls” — but they are not people in the usual sense either. Rather, they are bodies with replaced consciousness, levers, a working mechanism. They lose the ability to think rationally and become something like “worker bees” — an organism with a single function. This is, of course, very conditional. But they are precisely the ones who do not go insane like those who receive a “fragment”. 
 
 But you yourself say that they have a replaced consciousness... 
 
 Well, yes. Monolithians can carry their own special “pieces of the Monolith”, that is, their own special code that governs their behavior. But at the same time they must remain sane — on their own level, of course. Their role is to somehow lure new potential carriers of the “fragment”, and then to filter out those who are ready to leave, who have “ripened”, so to speak. And also to guard the approaches against those who are mentally opposed to the Monolith. 
 
 But surely something human remains in them? 
 
 Naturally. Not everyone becomes a Monolithian at once. In our universe nothing happens instantaneously, since the factor of time exists. Perhaps in the universe of the Monolith there is no time, but we are not meant to understand that. Therefore, a transitional process is assumed, when a person is not yet a Monolithian, but is no longer quite human either. Probably, in order to achieve some understanding of themselves on a human level, they need to explain these phenomena and this essence in some way. For example, through the creation of a cult, a religion — that is the easiest way for a human being to “understand” the incomprehensible. 
 
 By what criteria, then, does the Monolith choose those who will serve it, and those who will carry its “fragment”? 
 
 Here I can say nothing. If such criteria exist, they are unknown to us. It is impossible either to understand or to predict what something entirely from another world “thinks”. In that world, in theory, logic itself must be completely different — if it exists at all. 
 
 Alright, but if at the initial stage of “monolithization”, so to speak, one were somehow to erase the record or, as you put it, the Monolith’s “psychomatrix”, what would happen to the person? Would they become normal again and behave precisely like a human being? 
 
 Hard to say. It probably all depends on the depth of the influence. If the implanted “code” is insignificant, then most likely the human aspect of such an individual would prevail. But they would not remember certain things, because in place of the erased, conditionally speaking, “code”, the person would not regain the previous data that had been overwritten by that “code”... 
 
 ...
I’ve come across some papers, could you make sense of them?
What kind of papers? Where from?

Look, these documents are from one underground laboratory. I don’t know their contents, but there definitely must be something in them about the operation of the "Brain Scorcher". Right now it’s shut down and without power, and that’s a big mistake. It needs to be turned on, otherwise everyone will die. That’s the short version...

I’m not sure I want to get into the long version. Alright, I don’t really care either way.\nLet’s see what we’ve got here. Hm... There’s a ton of stuff here... This will take time. Judging by your flustered look, you want an answer as soon as possible, right? Let’s do it this way: I’ll put all my other work aside and deal with yours, and you’ll go for a walk for an hour or so... let’s say, three. Meanwhile, you’ll prepare the payment for my services — a third-level artifact. And make sure not a fly has sat on it, because I know you stalkers, you’ll bring something that’s been used to death, worn to the bone, on its last legs...
No problem, you’ll get a zero-mileage artifact.
So, any progress on my question about turning on the "Brain Scorcher"?
It was rather tricky, to be honest, but now I can generally satisfy your curiosity. Did you bring the payment?
A third-level artifact, fresh off the press. Here you go.
Hold on a bit, I’ll go fetch a suitable artifact.

Alright then. The bad news: starting the main power supply circuit is a lost cause. Only a team of specialists could handle that. The good news: somewhere beneath the Dark Valley, if I’ve matched the landmarks correctly, there is a backup geothermal generator. Logically, it should be in a standby state right now, but switching it to operational mode is many times easier than the main one. All that’s required is to open the circulation of the heat-transfer fluid, after which it will be possible to switch the facility’s power supply to the backup line.
Open the circulation of the heat-transfer fluid... So I just need to turn some main valve, right? And what about the power? How do I switch it?

Regarding the heat-transfer fluid, I think you’ve got it right. You literally need to look for the “main valve” and turn it. The automation doesn’t work if everything’s without power. As for the power supply, from the service correspondence of some engineer who was listed in the maintenance team assigned to the "Rainbow" complex, I managed to find out that in the same place where the backup generator is located, there is also a control post for it. What it looks like — I have no idea, but you can get inside if you have the access code:
That’s more or less clear. And then what? How do I fire the "Brain Scorcher" back up?

What I don’t know, I don’t know. There’s nothing about that in the documents. By analogy with the “main valve”, you probably need to look for the main switch. In theory, Ivar should know. After all, it was his guys who shut the installation down.

As for where the switch itself is located, I do have an idea — I’ve already been tipped off. The installation’s operation was controlled from yet another underground facility, the entrance to which is on Radar.\nListen, Docent, there’s one thought that won’t leave me alone. I consulted with one knowledgeable guy, and he dropped a phrase saying that the effect of the "Brain Scorcher" on people might just be a malfunction, an error. As if something is configured incorrectly. Working in the wrong phase or modulation. Something like that. What do you think, is that realistic?

Absolutely! I mean, if someone had deliberately planned to cover a specific area of the Zone with an impassable field for humans, who would need that and why? And to use such... to put it mildly, inhumane methods. To scare off outsiders, the good old ultrasound at a certain frequency would’ve been more than enough. But instead they’re breeding zombified... Using this kind of radiation as a pinpoint weapon — that’s one thing, but to “carpet-bomb” like this... No, something doesn’t add up here. I’m much more inclined to believe in an unintentional error, a malfunction, or even a side effect.\nHm... What if... It just might work...
What is it? What idea did you have?

Yeah. You know how it is when the right words reach a “critical mass”? Modulation, phase, frequency. And then — bam! An epiphany.\nAnyway, I remembered that your documents contained instructions for switching the installation’s operating modes. This is done using special blocks with programs recorded on them. They are installed into harmonizer-setters, which are actually responsible for tuning the radiation parameters. If you can get the right blocks, you can reset these parameters to “factory” or test settings, if you like. I’m almost certain that with such settings the radiation should become as safe as possible for organic life forms.

And where am I supposed to get these “right blocks” for you? Go look for some warehouse under Radar and shake down the local storekeeper? And he’ll rush at me with outstretched claws, chanting: soldier... sol-dier! Uh... sorry, my jokes are stupid.

Jokes aside, you guessed right about the warehouse. Only it’s not under Radar, but — you won’t believe it — once again under the Dark Valley. Hold on, I saw a waybill somewhere... Aha, here it is. The suitable blocks are marked 12-X-14TO. You’ll need to insert a couple of those into the third and fourth harmonizer, replacing the installed ones. The harmonizer-setters themselves, according to the records, are located at the facility indexed X-8. There’s even a photo of them here, you can keep it.

Ugh... Why is everything always so complicated?! Go there, then here, take this, go back... Alright, I got you. I’d better write the plan of action down in my PDA so I don’t get confused. And try to stick to it.

Docent helped make sense of Strelok’s papers. And even came up with a way to theoretically save the people who rushed beyond Radar, and who will inevitably die or turn into mindless zombies after the "Rainbow" is restarted. The plan is as follows:
1. Open the circulation of the heat-transfer fluid in the underground complex beneath the Dark Valley (look for the “main valve” and turn it).
2. The control post of the backup generator is located there as well. I copied down the code for the entrance door. You need to get inside and start that very generator.
3. Make your way to the warehouse and find two blocks for the harmonizer-setters marked 12-X-14TO.
4. Insert the found blocks into harmonizers number three and four, located at the facility indexed X-8.
5. By analogy with the “main valve”, look for the “main switch” to start the "Rainbow" installation. Its operation was controlled from a laboratory on Radar, the entrance to which is cut straight into the slope of a hill, which can be reached from the fork by moving along the road to the north.
Ivar, I forgot to tell you. I ran into your Seekers.
Did you? Where?
I met one on Radar. But that was before the "Brain Scorcher" was shut down. He mentioned you, blamed himself for being a coward, for not going with the others.
I understand... who you’re talking about. And where is he?
After that conversation I didn’t see him again. Maybe the monsters got him, maybe something else... Radar is a dead place, you know that yourself.
Well then... if he’s alive, he’ll show up. Anything else?

At "Tesla Zone", I happened to run into two more. They were sitting in an old cellar. What dragged them there? One was in really bad shape, not long for this world, that’s a fact. Whether they got out or not, I don’t know. Maybe they’re still sitting in that basement.

At "Tesla Zone", I happened to run into two more. One was in really bad shape, not long for this world, that’s a fact. I helped them — gave them batteries. Whether they got out of there or not, I don’t know.

At "Tesla Zone", I happened to run into two more. One was in really bad shape, not long for this world, that’s a fact. I helped them — gave them batteries. One of them did manage to get out. Last time I saw him in Limansk. He said once he recovers, he’ll go looking for you. As I understand it, he hasn’t come here.
I just wanted to let you know. So you’d be aware.
Yeah... Listen, Marked One. Not as a duty, but as a favor... could you bring me a suit? I need it... badly.
Are you serious, planning to go somewhere?! You still need to sit here and sit until you come to your senses.

I’m already... better. And you can’t just sit forever. There’s work to be done... My comrade... from our group... died when we were breaking through to the "Brain Scorcher", in the northern part of the forest... find him, if it’s not too much trouble... He had a suit... we got it from Sakharov... new... experimental... I need one like that, for the job.
Radar?! That’s quite a request you’ve got... Maybe I’ll bring it. I can see you can’t be held back here anyway...
You... do try. I’ll repay you... I left something here... with the Docent... some time ago...
Hi, Ivar. I found the armor and... the body, of your friend.
Yeah... that’s a shame. Well then, now I can start getting ready...
Take the armor, but if I were you, I wouldn’t rush to leave the Bar. You’re still weak.
I can’t... sit around without work. Thanks... you helped me out. Take this... artifact.
I’ll be going, and you get some rest.
Ivar, I have a question for you. Did you know Strelok well?
No, not at all. Just a passing acquaintance.
Then why did he give you those papers?

I told you why I came here. It all started with former stalkers who returned from the Zone, where they had developed severe mental disorders of a schizo... phrenic nature. That’s how they came to the attention of my colleagues. Every single one of them spoke of some incomprehensible fragment that they had supposedly lost. At first I thought it was some special artifact. Then I learned about the “Black Mark”. I thought it was what was driving people insane. In the end I came to the conclusion that the only way to understand what was going on was to personally visit the Zone.
That’s all clear. You said that eventually you decided the “Brain Scorcher” was to blame. But where does Strelok fit into this story? How did he find you?

How — that I don’t know. In principle, many people had heard about our group back then, so finding us if one wanted to wasn’t difficult at all.\nAt that time I still knew almost nothing about the “Brain Scorcher”, but I was looking for any information about radiation whose source was somewhere on Radar. How did I first meet Strelok? One night he simply showed up at our temporary camp at the Army Warehouses in the middle of the night. The sentries missed him — he seemed to appear out of nowhere. He went straight to the point, saying that he knew about our research and was ready to help. In exchange for the materials of my re... search on the connection between the “Black Mark” and the obsessive states of its bearer.
As far as I know, that artifact is a nightmare for any stalker. Only a few survive who manage to “earn” it. Why was Strelok interested in it?

It’s not that simple. Yes, on the one hand, the “Mark” has an extremely negative ef... fect on the body and in some cases even leads to death, but those who were lucky enough to survive it acquire... how should I put it... a kind of immunity, perhaps, to certain types of psi-activity. Note — precisely those who survived the “Mark”, not those who found a way to get rid of it. Obviously, this trait manifests itself at the moment the degenerated artifact breaks down.
I see. You mean that if you’ve “been through” the “Black Mark”, you can safely go for a stroll even under the “Brain Scorcher”?

No. The radiation of the “Brain Scorcher” has a different nature. It’s a man-made object and, as we now know, it was configured to block the spread of the field of apathy. Immunity protects against certain types of, if I may say so, natural psi-activity. That is, things directly connected with the Zone. With the Monolith, if you like. As you probably understand, this topic is not the easiest to study. There is extremely little statistical and, more importantly, objective data, but I still managed to draw some conclusions.
So those with immunity aren’t afraid of controllers? Dogs don’t fry their brains? No double vision after teleportations? Something like that?

Well... I’d say that the nega... tive effects of the phenomena you listed would be reduced to some extent, but that’s not the main point. The “Black Mark” is something like a friend-or-foe test for the Monolith. By what principle those tested are selected, I don’t know, but the fact remains — the immune are not susceptible to the Monolith’s “virus” and cannot be its carriers. Those very “lost fragment” types. If you’ve forgotten what that’s about, reread Strelok’s notes.
No, I remember. So was Strelok really that afraid of getting infected with this “virus”?

I think he simply wanted to obtain the “friend” marker for the Monolith. Who knows how recognition mechanisms work in alien organisms, but I suppose it must be similar to how the human immune system functions. It can always distinguish its own cells from harmful pathogens. Though, of course, under certain conditions there can be failures. Take cancer, for example...
So that means... That means Strelok wanted, roughly speaking, to disguise himself as one of its own in order to get close to the Monolith and... What then? Destroy it? Neutralize it? But how?

I’d like to know the answer to that myself. In any case, he had a problem with the “Black Mark”. As I understood it, for some reason he himself could not obtain it in a nat... ural way, if one can put it that way. After some time, having familiarized himself with my research, he began searching for carriers of the “Mark”. Well, you won’t meet many of those in the nearest stalker camp, obviously. Later I heard rumors that he and some scientist were working on creating a device capable of protecting artifacts from rapid degeneration. I can assume that his main motive once again was to find a way to con... serve the “Mark”, to preserve it in our world for as long as possible.
What an intriguer... So where did he eventually disappear to, any ideas? I can’t believe he could just perish in some dark basement, running into a bloodsucker.

It seems to me that Strelok tried to get to the Monolith to the very end. And it ended badly for him. According to him, he was making his way beyond the “Rainbow” through old underground communications. And supposedly there is even a path underground all the way to the Sarcophagus through some tunnels, but I remember Strelok saying they were flooded and therefore useless. Don’t ask for details, I don’t know them. First, this information didn’t seem wor... thy of attention to me at the time, and second, he wasn’t particularly fond of being frank about side topics not directly related to our agreement.\nIn short, if you want my opinion, Strelok died somewhere on the approaches to the CNPP or right there. Alternatively, he fell under the control of the Monolith.
Yeah... The mysteries only keep multiplying. I need to think all this over. You get some rest for now.
I wanted to ask you something about temporal teleporters.
What exactly interests you? It’s a rather slippery topic and it’s easy to drift from scientific assumptions into fantasy.
You do know something about them.
Know? Hardly. More like hypothesize. So what interests you?
Well, how to explain it... The Zone, it sort of grows. That’s what I’ve heard. And that means the number of all kinds of bubbles, passages, holes in space grows too.
I can’t fault your logic. And?..
Well, that means there could be more time teleporters as well. Or maybe it’s already easier to get into them, not accidentally, but deliberately...
I see...
Do you think someone could deliberately come to us from the future?
For what purpose?
Well... For example, to put an end to all this. Stop it. Destroy the Monolith... For instance.
I find it interesting to follow the course of your reasoning, but I must disappoint you. Even if we assume something like that, he still wouldn’t be able to change anything.
Why?

Because you can’t change cause and effect! It’s impossible to break the sequence of events. At least if we’re talking about the world around us, and not speculating about black holes... Do you understand?
Not really... After all, if there is some teleporter that can take you into the past, why couldn’t someone use it? And destroy, for example, that same Monolith?

Oh, these stalker myths about the Monolith... You’re so fixated on it. Stalkers invented a fairy tale and tell it to each other. Why would you want to destroy it then? If according to your stalker beliefs it “grants wishes”? Or what does it do there? Hands out happiness to everyone...
Me personally, I don’t really need to. I’m just... For example, if someone decided that the Monolith was the cause of all troubles, or something like that... I’ve read some things about it.

Get that nonsense out of your head... \nAlthough, let’s speculate for amusement. Suppose that in the future someone decided that a certain Monolith had become... uh, bad, dangerous. And decided to travel into the past to change the situation. So then, proceeding from the fact that you can’t change cause and effect, it turns out that it became dangerous there in the future precisely because here, “in the past”, someone attempted to destroy it... Follow my thought?
I’m trying.

This is a reaction to what was done. A response of that Monolith, or whoever else — that’s not the point... That is, the visitor from the future theoretically becomes the very cause of what happened there in his time, but in the future he doesn’t realize this and thinks that he is fixing the situation now, whereas in reality he himself is creating it. In short — a time loop... You look discouraged.
Yeah, it’s all kind of complicated...

I’m only trying to prove to you the impossibility of your assumptions. And speaking more simply, in everyday terms, nothing that has already happened can be changed. No matter how hard you try. No-thing!
That’s exactly what upsets me...
Well then, my friend, so we’ve finally met.
Ghost, as I understand?
You recognized me? Strange, you shouldn’t have. Or do you remember me after all?
You called me here to talk about my memories?
Not without that. I’m very curious about what’s there — in your memories. And whether they’re even yours.

Listen! If we know each other, speak plainly! Why are you dodging? And besides, if you’re really who you claim to be, then you must know Strelok. Where is he, and how am I connected to him and your group?
Just like that, straight into it? First I’d like to hear what you actually remember. Then I’ll answer some of your questions.

What business is it of yours what I remember? Yes, I lost my memory, woke up in a little village on the Cordon. Thanks to Sidorovich and the Doctor for not letting me die. Little by little, some things are starting to surface in my head. Doc thinks that the more I roam the Zone, the more I talk to people, the higher the chance I’ll run into acquaintances from my “past life”. Talking to them could spur my consciousness and another piece of the puzzle will fall into place. There’s one more lead to my past — Strelok. That’s all you need to know.

Ah! So the Doctor didn’t tell you everything? Wants to keep his hands clean. Like he had nothing to do with it at all. Crafty old man...\nAnswer for answer. We really do know each other, if you can put it that way. But I know almost nothing about you. You’ve met Ivar, right? He, on the other hand, knows perfectly well who you are.

Ivar?! He really did drop something during our conversation like “you remind me of someone, but no, you can’t be him”. I didn’t attach much importance to it, since he himself was... not quite himself.
Yeah. What irony. Tried to cure poor zombies and nearly joined their ranks himself. And it was he who brought you to Strelok in the first place. Didn’t confess, did he? Tsk-tsk!
WHAT?! What is that supposed to mean? Explain yourself!

Instead of listening to my explanations, you’d better pin Ivar to the wall properly and ask him straight out yourself. Though... you might later regret choosing knowledge over soothing ignorance. Here and now you are a brave and lucky stalker, Marked One. But what if there, beyond the perimeter, you’re, say, a simple plumber? Living in a one-room Khrushchevka somewhere near Chernihiv with a dim-witted wife and a son who’s a juvenile delinquent. You don’t have a penny to your name, just debts. Every evening you booze it up at a local dive with a bunch of the same losers, out of hopelessness and the realization that nothing good awaits you in life anymore.
Did you spend long inventing my biography? And even if all of that turned out to be true, I still have to know who I am, who I was.

Are you sure? Then allow me to add a couple of details to my “fiction”. One day you drink yourself into delirium tremens and end up in a madhouse, and in your apartment they find the bodies of your family. After coming to your senses a bit and realizing what you’ve done, you escape from the hospital and hide in the Zone. What do you say?

You’re lying about everything! I know you’re a vile and slippery type who wouldn’t hesitate to commit any filth to achieve your goals. I just can’t yet figure out what you’re plotting with regard to me.

To begin with, I’m interested in what drives you. I’ve been watching you for a long time. You climb into the very hell no one else would dare enter. For what? Really, it’s not just the desire to regain your memory and understand yourself that makes you go time and again where even I wouldn’t risk setting foot. You invented that excuse just so you wouldn’t seem like a lunatic to yourself. In reality, you’re quite comfortable even without your lost memories. And don’t say you’ve never thought about it.

Maybe you’re right. Sometimes I myself don’t understand what pushes me so stubbornly to continue the search. The secrets of the Zone? The mythical call of the Monolith? The hope of finally understanding myself? Possibly all of it together.

I’ll throw in another possible reason. You’re being led by a part of Strelok’s consciousness that was merged with your personality as a result of an extremely unusual experiment. Strelok himself considered it a failure, but between us, he was a master of obfuscation and left many things unsaid. I’d really like to know what he was trying to achieve and how he intended to use you.
You know, that’s already too much! I...
Ivar didn’t happen to let you read Strelok’s notes, did he?
What? Uh... Notes? The ones about the Monolith and our possible future?
Ours or not ours, but yours — definitely. And quite possibly the very near one.
My future? I don’t understand...
I’m talking about that passage where the guardians of the Monolith are mentioned. As I understand it, that’s exactly what awaits you in the near future.
There was nothing there about any guardians. Are you trying to mess with my head again?

So Strelok didn’t give Ivar everything. Then read what I’m uploading to your PDA now. For the sake of completeness, so to speak. Back in the day I allowed myself to make copies of the files from Strelok’s flash drive, which he carelessly left in... one of our group’s secret hideouts while hastily preparing for a raid.\nOnce you’ve read it, go see Ivar and ask him why he brought you to Strelok. While you’re at it, drop by the Doctor as well. Tell them you met me and that I laid my cards on the table. Otherwise they’ll start wriggling again. I guarantee you’ll learn a lot of interesting things about yourself. Then think it all over properly and come back. We’ll talk in more concrete terms.
Alright, I’ll do as you say. But keep in mind, if anything happens... In short, I’ll find you. And then our conversation will take on a very different tone.
You will, you will. I’m not going anywhere. I’ll be here. After all, you guessed the main thing — I do have certain plans for you.
Marked One, back again? Find anything out?
I will. I definitely will.
Back already? Talk to Ivar and the Doctor?
I did, I definitely did. Now it’s time to have a word with you, to dot all the i’s, so to speak. Brief and to the point, without lyrical digressions.
Ooh, how businesslike we are. Well then, ask your questions.
Do you know who I am?
No.
Do you know where Strelok is?
No.
Tell me about Strelok’s experiments in the Foggy Thicket.

I can only speak about that in the most general terms. Only Strelok himself knew exactly what was being done there and why. He had a fixation — to reach the Monolith and destroy it. And on that “dead Monolith” in the Foggy Thicket, he was planning to test a device to see how the “real” Monolith might react. There were other experiments as well, but all of them, as I understand it, revolved around this same main goal.
How am I connected to these experiments?

You were found in the Foggy Thicket, near the site of one of them. Strelok said it was as if you fell out of nowhere. Stranger things than that happen in the Thicket — you’ve probably noticed by now. Knowing Strelok, I assumed it was hardly a simple coincidence. He probably didn’t even go to the toilet without a reason. For every “sneeze” he always had an explanation, and for every event — his own thoughts. I asked him point-blank: why did you need this stalker? Strelok just shrugged and repeated that everything that had happened was a misunderstanding, a tragic accident. Asked me to take care of that guy — well, that is, of you.
I see... so, in your opinion, why might I have been useful to him?

At first I decided you were meant to play the role of a “key”. You’ve heard the stories, I assume, that the Zone can let you into certain places only through a sacrifice? Think it’s all fairy tales? I’ve actually encountered that.
Nonsense! Then he wouldn’t have cared about my health. What kind of sacrifice is it that they then treat and nurse back to health?

I thought the same, so I soon discarded this version. Then I started looking for another reason and remembered our argument about transferring consciousness. Not that I seriously believed such a thing was possible, but... Those strange devices and installations he either got hold of somewhere or assembled with Fang’s hands... I’m not very strong technically, but here’s what occurred to me: could Strelok, under the guise of one experiment, have carried out a completely different one?
Are you hinting that he transferred or swapped consciousnesses — even if only partially — with me? But why?

Who knows. Strelok, as I’ve already said, was striving with all his might to reach the Monolith. And he almost succeeded — but only almost. Something was in his way. He lacked some final piece of the mosaic. And I don’t rule out that he tried to obtain that missing element from you.
What element? I don’t... Hm. But the Monolithians almost took me for one of their own. As if I have some kind of sign or mark...

There you go. You’re thinking. It seems to me that this peculiarity of yours will allow you to reach the Monolith itself. Worth trying, don’t you think? Maybe you’ll find Strelok there too, and in general...

And yet the Doctor warned me that you would try to persuade me to go to the Monolith. You’d sing like a nightingale, just to find out how to get there yourself. I know that you didn’t share Strelok’s views regarding the Monolith, and as for its destruction — that was the last thing you wanted.
I wasn’t going to hide from you that I have a different opinion on this matter. If the Monolith is truly capable of granting wishes, just imagine how much good that could...

Drop these attempts, Ghost. I don’t believe in your pious intentions and altruism. Be that as it may, I see no other way for myself than to try to repeat Strelok’s path. And that means I have only one road — to the CNPP. And what I’ll do if I reach the Monolith... we’ll see then.
Believe it or not, that suits me just fine. By the way, since you speak so confidently, maybe you already know how you’ll get to the CNPP? I’ve heard there’s no direct route there now.
Uh... Actually no, but it’s alright, I’ll find a way — wouldn’t be the first time.

Let me save you some time. I know that shortly before his disappearance, Strelok visited Pripyat, where he spoke with a certain Lebed the Liaison. This guy runs all the fanatics in the city. I suppose that since they guard the approaches to the station, they must know how to get there most easily and quickly. Something tells me this Lebed won’t refuse to share this information with you.

Sounds reasonable. Pripyat, then Pripyat. Yes, one last question. Why did you badmouth Ivar and try to turn me against the Doctor? Part of what you said during our last meeting was an outright lie, while another part was confirmed.
I wanted to see how you’d react. I told you I had several theories about you and wasn’t completely sure who I was dealing with. Consider it just a test.

Uh-huh. I’ll pretend I believed you. Alright, it’s time for me to get ready for the road. I wouldn’t advise you to trail after me. I’m not a “key”, whatever you may think. I sincerely hope we won’t meet again.

Who knows how it will all turn out. It may yet happen that you yourself will come looking for a meeting with me.\nAh, yes, one more thing. If you remember, I told you that I managed to make copies of files from Strelok’s flash drive, which he forgot in one of our hideouts. So, among other things, there was a map with marked locations of stash placements at the CNPP. Who made them and when, I don’t know, but they may come in very handy for you.\nThat’s it, I wish you good luck! I hope you have enough strength to go this path to the end.
Putting off the inevitable?
I wanted to tell you about Fang. I thought you might find it interesting. You’ve been in harness with him for a long time, right?

Well, basically yes. Sakharov has already had time to complain to me that you lost some device that was issued to you to get Fang to the surface and deliver him to the scientists. But I still didn’t fully understand: did you help Fang or not?
I helped. But not in the way the professor would have liked. I sent him to the Foggy Thicket, to the Doctor.
What? So he’s still here, in the Zone?!

Well, yes. He’s lying low in a cave. He picked it out for his needs a long time ago and knows it like the back of his hand. So he’s quite comfortable there... if that word is appropriate in his circumstances. I think sooner or later the Doctor will find a way to cure him. Or he and Ivar will figure something out together.

Yeah... That’s some help, alright. The scientists offered you a real option to save him. Fang could have been taken beyond the perimeter and handled by real specialists. And here what chances does he have? Some kind uncle brings a miracle artifact and everything goes back to normal? Ah well... What’s done is done.

I know those specialists — I’ve seen enough of them already. Successors of Doctor Mengele. And what did you yourself do for Fang? You knew for sure from the Doctor that he was at Agroprom. Did you go to Sakharov for advice or come up with something useful? Did you even drop by once to see how he was doing, to cheer him up a bit? Pfah... You’d better keep quiet than criticize others.
Ivar, I’ve got business with you. Do you remember you let slip that I remind you of someone?
Did I say that? No. I don’t remember...
I met with Ghost. And he claims that you know me. More than that — that it was you who brought me to Strelok.
What?! No! I don’t know what games Ghost is playing or why he’s slandering me, but...
What “but”? Finish your thought. You did recognize me, didn’t you? I was one of your patients? Beyond the perimeter? Or already here, in the Zone?
Calm down, friend. Yes, you really did remind me of someone, but now, when things in my head have cleared up a bit, I’m increasingly doubting that it could have been you.
That won’t do. Tell it in order.

All right. Once I arranged to meet Strelok in the Red Forest. He wanted to clarify something regarding the materials I had passed on to him concerning the effects of the “Black Mark” on the bearer’s body. I, as you can imagine, also had questions for him. When I arrived at the meeting place, to my surprise it turned out that Strelok hadn’t come alone. Ghost was with him, and another unfamiliar stalker. All three of them were sitting by the campfire, and when Strelok noticed me, he stood up to meet me and immediately led me aside. Apparently, he didn’t want the others to overhear our conversation.
That third stalker — that was me, right?
Dusk was already falling, so I couldn’t really make him out properly. He was sitting half-turned away from me, his head lowered. On top of that, part of his face was hidden by the hood of his suit.
And still?
I already told you: I think it wasn’t you. There was some resemblance, but nothing more. From that angle and in that lighting, anyone could have been mistaken for someone else.
Then why, in that conversation of ours, did you exclaim something like “you can’t be him”? By your own words now, it turns out there was no reason for such categorical statements.

All right... I’ll tell you. That man... he looked extremely exhausted. And in general it seemed to me that he behaved overly listlessly, like a somnambulist. These and some other details of his appearance indicated that he’d had the bad luck to “catch” the notorious “Black Mark”. I think Strelok wanted to conduct some kind of experiment on him...
Why did you decide that?

When I was approaching the campfire, Strelok was animatedly arguing with Ghost about the psychomatrix and either the transfer of consciousness or the overlaying of one consciousness onto another. Only fragments of phrases reached me, but the general sense of the conversation, as I understood it, boiled down to Strelok trying to convince Ghost to test some theory of his in practice. At the same time, either one or the other would alternately point a finger or nod in the direction of the third stalker, and he didn’t react at all, as if none of it concerned him.
Well I’ll be damned! And what kind of theory did Strelok have? You didn’t ask him about it?

I asked in passing, but he just waved it off. Said he’d tell me sometime later, that he didn’t have time right now. And indeed, after talking about urgent matters, they immediately started getting ready to move out. And I headed back to our camp. I remember hearing, just before I left, how Ghost asked Strelok: “Are you sure this can only be done in the Thicket?” After that meeting I saw Strelok one more time, but I’ve already told you about that. Then I was completely consumed by the idea that the increase in strange mental disorders beyond the perimeter was connected with the operation of the “Brain Scorcher”, and I didn’t try to learn more about Strelok’s experiments.

I see. And you decided that that... “test subject” was most likely already a goner anyway, having caught the “Black Mark”, and after Strelok’s experiments — all the more so. And here I am, seemingly alive and kicking, standing in front of you, pestering you with questions. Which means I can’t be that man. There’s logic in that. But what if Strelok actually did manage to somehow swap consciousness with that stalker? Fully or partially. And the “mark” jumped to him. You yourself told me how he strove to obtain it in order to become “one of his own” for the Monolith...
Yeah... if Ghost’s goal was to confuse you, then he definitely succeeded. You’ve got quite the imagination, Marked One. That’s quite a twist you’ve put on my words...

Wait! Let me finish the thought. It turns out that if you really didn’t mistake me, and it truly was me you saw back then, and then Strelok did something to me because of which I lost my memory... Am I just the result of his failed experiment? Or was it a success after all?! He got what he was aiming for, do you think?

Your suspiciousness will get you killed one day, Marked One. For the tenth time I repeat: I think it was another person. And Ghost is deliberately trying to generate as much white noise as possible, feeding you far-fetched versions. I can’t for the life of me understand why he’s doing this.

Yeah, yeah, sure. And here I was racking my brain over where these strange “memories” came from and why I doubt that they’re mine... Turns out it could easily be that none of it is mine at all. And how am I even supposed to understand now whose is whose in my head? Maybe I’m just going crazy, huh, Ivar?

Pull yourself together at last! As a specialist, I assure you: you show no signs of insanity whatsoever.\nYes, the Doctor correctly noted that you’re highly suggestible. Under no circumstances should you be pushed toward any particular idea — you must arrive at everything yourself...
The Doctor talked to you about me?! You discussed my... what do you doctors call it... case? And what did the council of learned men decide in my regard?
I don’t understand your sarcasm. The Doctor is genuinely very worried about you. He asked for advice.
And what advice did you give him?

Basically, I only confirmed the correctness of the strategy initially chosen. You needed to be shielded from direct suggestion, only given a general direction, attempts made to bring you together with old acquaintances, to persuade you to visit places you’d been to before, in order to subtly push your consciousness toward searching for your inner “I”.
Well, thanks. You pushed it so well it nearly smashed its face when it fell.\nAll right, I’ll go talk to the Doctor now. It’s time to decide something already...
Doctor, I need to have a serious talk with you. I met with Ghost.
Is that so? I was racking my brain over how to let Ghost know that he should finally reach out to you. And it turns out you managed to talk without my “matchmaking” after all. Very good.

What’s so good about it? He told me such things... For example, that it was Ivar who brought me to Strelok. That I had supposedly been his patient back there, beyond the perimeter. That I drank without drying out until one day I snapped and killed my family. Then I ended up in a madhouse and escaped from there into the Zone. He also said that you know a lot about me, but are keeping quiet.

What nonsense?! Of course, I don’t know your past, but I’m certain he clearly made up that biography. I’ve seen many people in my lifetime, and believe me, you don’t look like a drunkard wastrel, nor a deranged psycho, let alone a murderer.\nAs for Strelok... As far as I know, Strelok merely consulted Ivar on some questions from his field of expertise. Something about the connection between mental disorders and the artifact known as the “Black Mark”. Ivar is a doctor. He would never put his patient in danger by agreeing to...

Why did you stop? By agreeing to what? To Strelok’s experiment? Yes, yes, I already know about that too. Before coming to you, I talked to Ivar. He told me about a strange stalker he saw in the company of Strelok and Ghost. It seems the poor guy had the bad luck to get hit with the “Black Mark”, and Strelok was planning to conduct some kind of experiment on him. When I met Ivar in the Bar after the trip to the “Brain Scorcher”, he seemed to recognize that unfortunate stalker in me, but later backed out, saying he must have been mistaken.
I see you’ve indeed found out quite a lot, only you’re drawing the wrong conclusions. It seems Ghost deliberately decided to confuse you. But for what purpose, I’d really like to know?
Don’t steer the conversation aside. What do you know about Strelok’s experiment and my — or perhaps not my — role in it?

All right. I suppose there really is no point in continuing to hide this now. I don’t know exactly what experiments Strelok was conducting or what exactly he was trying to achieve. I do know there were several of them, and they all took place in the Foggy Thicket, near the ravine at the bottom of which stands the “dead Monolith”. It’s a huge crystal around which all instruments that measure the intensity of the psi-field go off the scale. Some believe that it is a fragment of that very legendary Monolith...
To hell with the Monolith! Get to the point.

Don’t get so worked up, Marked One. I’m getting to the essence. One day the whole trio showed up at my hut: Fang, Ghost, and Strelok. I knew that the day before they had once again been fiddling with some equipment near the “dead Monolith”, so their appearance didn’t surprise me. What did surprise me was that they were carrying another person on improvised stretchers. He was unconscious. And that was you, Marked One.
So it’s true after all... And what happened next?

According to Strelok, shortly after completing the tests of some installation assembled by Fang according to his design, they found a stalker unconscious within its area of effect, showing signs of psi-radiation damage. Apparently, it was an absurd accident. You were simply in the wrong place at the wrong time.
Or very much the opposite — in exactly the right place, at exactly the right time. So what about the transfer or overlaying of consciousness, huh, Doc?
What did you say? Transfer of consciousness? Are you serious? Is that even possible? Did Ghost spin that tale for you too?

No, Ivar. He managed to partially overhear an argument between Strelok and Ghost. That’s exactly what it was about. True, Ivar was far away and didn’t catch everything... And why did I even assume that Strelok was going to experiment on that stalker? Just because Ivar saw that pair nodding in his direction?!

There you go. You’re already starting to doubt yourself. A vivid confirmation of how easily you succumb to manipulation and suggestion. Now imagine how you would have reacted if I had immediately told you everything I knew. Would you have believed me?

The question is different: should I believe what you’re saying now? It seems I’m completely tangled up... All right, I’ll listen to your version to the end. What happened after they brought me to your hut?

Strelok almost immediately said his goodbyes and went off on his own business, instructing Ghost to take care of you. It seems he felt guilty about the misfortune that had befallen you. I gave you first aid and asked Ghost and Fang to carry you to a safer place, where you lay recovering for quite a long time. By the way, you were there later, after your recovery. It’s the group’s secret hideout in the underground tunnels of Agroprom. From my observations, recovery after a strong psi-strike proceeds the faster the closer the victim is to the borders of the Zone, but in your case, for some reason, everything went rather slowly, so we took turns watching over you: me, Fang, and Ghost.

So that’s why I had the feeling I’d already been there before... And I knew how to get into the hideout itself. But no details stuck in my head. Wait! But I was found by Ginger near that truck on the Cordon... How?

Honestly? I don’t know. That day I was sitting with you, but after receiving an urgent request for help from an acquaintance, I was forced to leave my watch for a short while. I don’t know what made you get up and make your way out of the underground tunnels... There was a powerful emission then, one of the strongest I can remember. Maybe it affected you somehow, or you simply came to for a time and went on “autopilot” in a familiar direction, or something else... Be that as it may, when I returned, you were already gone without a trace. The next day I was informed that you had been found on the Cordon, and I went there. Thus was born the legend of the lone survivor from the “death truck”. In the village, when you gradually started coming to your senses, we properly met for the first time. The rest you already know.

Well, your version sounds fairly plausible, but don’t take it amiss, I’m no longer going to take anything on faith. It seems I have no other choice but to keep heading north. I hope there I’ll finally understand why Strelok was so drawn there, and perhaps even find him himself.
You’re talking about the Monolith? But...
Yes, I know, I know. Strelok most likely wanted to destroy it. Everything points to that. But either he failed, or... his goal was different after all.

I can’t vouch for Strelok, but Ghost definitely held a different point of view — that the Monolith must not be destroyed under any circumstances. They argued about this more than once. I think Ghost secretly dreams of putting the Monolith to work for himself, and therefore gathers any information about it that he can. Perhaps he wouldn’t mind persuading you to go to the Monolith, in order to observe from the sidelines what would come of it.\nIn any case, whatever you’re planning, I wish you luck, Marked One! This will be your most dangerous foray into the Zone — prepare yourself thoroughly and finish all your business. Who knows what awaits you there. It’s not worth dragging along the burden of unfulfilled promises and unsolved mysteries.
The main mystery for me is who I really am. It’s time to grab Ghost firmly by the throat. Farewell.
The main mystery for me is who I really am. It’s time to grab Ghost firmly by the throat. And I’d like to see Fang one last time as well — then I’m off. Farewell.
Doctor? What’s happening? How did I end up in the Foggy Thicket?
I thought you’d tell me what you were doing here. There was a bright flash on the other side of the hill. I went to check it out and found you near the “dead Monolith”.
But how did I get there? So does that mean it transported me?!
I don’t understand you at all, Marked One. Who transported you? You were heading on a raid to the north, weren’t you?

Yes... And I managed to repeat Strelok’s path by visiting the CNPP. There I found his notes and thought I could reach the Monolith using them. In the end, I found myself in some underground complex, but all the passages there were completely sealed. Then I noticed a teleport bubble, stepped into it, and ended up here...
Incredible! You came closer to the secret of the Monolith than anyone else! If we don’t count Strelok himself, of course.

It seems to me that Strelok also failed to unravel it. Something didn’t let him through. Just like me, as it happens... But I understood everything. Or almost everything. True... it no longer matters.
Are you still angry with me? Don’t you want to share what was revealed to you there?

No, I’m no longer angry. You did the right thing. If you had told me everything you knew about me right away, I probably wouldn’t have dared to follow Strelok’s trail to the end — I wouldn’t have had the nerve. And so I would still be stuck in confusion, doubt, and self-examination. But now... what’s happened has happened. Nothing can be fixed anyway, nothing can be changed. Strelok understood this too, I think. And he left. Completely.
Are you sure? How do you know?

I told you, I found his notes. His last notes, I think. I don’t know where he came from or where he is now, but here, in the Zone, he definitely isn’t. If he was from the future, he could have returned back, to his own time. Or to some other one. He came to terms with the fact that it’s impossible to change the past, no matter how hard you try, no matter what technologies you possess. You can’t change cause and effect. All his attempts were doomed from the start, and now we all have to live with this Zone and with this Monolith one way or another. And as for me... I have a feeling that my last trip wasn’t in vain.
What do you mean?

How do you know?
Well, damn! And are you sure that “witness” didn’t make it all up himself? Or didn’t mix him up with someone else? What was his name, by the way?

Diodor wrote that confession down right there, on the body. You were looking for Ryaboy — here you go, read it. You can keep it, there’s no point passing it on to Ryaboy now, and I don’t need it, our guys have all read it anyway.
Am I sure? No, of course not. I don’t know him personally at all. But why would he make up such a story? And our guys just called him by his name — Tokha.
I’ll read it.

Huh... There are plenty of Tokhas in the Zone! Ryaboy is dead, and it looks like I won’t be finding the last person who saw him alive. And what would that even give me? It’s unlikely they knew each other. Another dead end. Damn...
So where did Ivar go?
What am I, your Ivar’s babysitter?
Well, you never know. He didn’t drop by here?
He did, bought a few things and left. I didn’t pry into his plans. These days everyone’s heading north, so he probably went there too.
I see.
Did Ivar stop by to see you?
He did before leaving, asked for a working PDA.
And where did he go?

Who knows? Seemed like he was going to gather what was left of his group. They searched and searched for something and never found it, only got lost themselves. But he’s back to normal now, he’ll take care of himself. Though if he really wants to find the “Black Mark”, then hardly...
The Mark? What does he need it for?
That’s a question! How would I know? Or maybe I misunderstood him... Ivar took a hard hit after all, and his speech hasn’t fully recovered yet.
Strange. He mentioned that Strelok was interested in the “Black Mark”... What else did Ivar say?
Nothing really, said goodbye and that was it. Mumbled something like “Strelok might have been right” or something along those lines. I was busy, you know? Didn’t listen too closely.
Did you ever talk with him about flooded tunnels and pumps? Maybe not this time, but earlier? Or maybe you yourself know something about it? Found something like that in papers or on a PDA... No?
Did you ever talk with him about flooded tunnels and pumps? Maybe not this time, but earlier?

We didn’t talk about anything like that with Ivar, but... I think I came across references to documentation on this topic... If memory serves, it should be searched for in the underground laboratory with index X-12. And why do you need all this, if it’s not a secret?
Definitely not. As far as I remember, something like that flashed by in the papers you brought me recently. So you really got the urge to clarify this topic in more detail?
Just want to check one guess. Thanks for the tip, Docent. I’ll go get ready for the road...
Yeah, I did. So will you help? This is extremely important to me right now.
Yeah, I did. Listen, I helped you with your financial problems, so now you return the favor. This is extremely important to me right now.
And it’s extremely important for me to sort out my financial problems. By the way, I already stated my price on this matter — two third-tier artifacts in good condition. Forgot, didn’t you?

Well... Yes, of course, I’ll help however I can. I’ll still owe you anyway.\nWait a bit, I’ll check my notes on the laptop. All info that might be of interest to me or to those who regularly come to me, like you for example, I prefer to convert into electronic format.\nOh-ho... I don’t want to upset you, Marked One, but I can’t really tell you anything particularly useful about the tunnel-pumps. Except that control of the power supply and control of the pumps themselves are carried out from different locations. And the pumping installations themselves are located somewhere in a third place altogether. Something like that...
With you around, you’d forget how indeed. You never miss a chance to remind me how much I owe you. Here are the artifacts, satisfied?
Didn’t forget, didn’t forget. You’ll get your artifacts.
Hmph... I expected more. What use is this information to me...

Quite so. Wait a bit, I’ll check my notes on the laptop. All info that might be of interest to me or to those who regularly come to me, like you for example, I prefer to convert into electronic format.\nOh-ho... I don’t want to upset you, Marked One, but I can’t really tell you anything particularly useful about the tunnel-pumps. Except that control of the power supply and control of the pumps themselves are carried out from different locations. And the pumping installations themselves are located somewhere in a third place altogether. Something like that...

I understand your dissatisfaction, Marked One. I admit, I myself am baffled. It seemed to me that the last time I skimmed through the papers you brought, there was much more there... Stop! What an idiot I am! Remember how I told you that some guy tried to sell me similar documents, and I didn’t take them?
Are you kidding me? And I gave you two excellent artifacts for this information? That’s not how business is done, Docent...

I understand your indignation, Marked One. I admit, I myself can’t make sense of how it turned out this way. It seemed to me that the last time I skimmed through the papers you brought, there was much more there... Stop! What an idiot I am! Remember how I told you that some guy tried to sell me similar documents, and I didn’t take them?
Oh no! Don’t tell me you mixed up which documents you found what I desperately need in now! And what am I supposed to do? What was that stalker’s name, where do I look for him now?

Alas, that’s the kind of blunder it was... What was his name, what was his name... I honestly don’t remember. I saw him that day for the first and last time. Where to look — no idea either. Although... there is one lead. When I politely asked him to leave, he blurted out something like “well, screw you, I’ll sell it to Tooth.” If the deal went through, then go to that trader. As far as I know, he should be in Limansk now.\nOh, and one more thing: some suspicious-looking guy was hanging around here recently. First talked to the Barman about something, then came to see me. He also asked about tunnels, underground laboratories, and some kind of tools. But I brushed him off, said I didn’t know anything. He seemed way too shady to me.

Aha! Tooth buys up everything, so there’s a chance. That guy’s no gift, of course, but you can deal with him. Especially if you offer the right price. All right, let’s say you helped me. And about the suspicious guy — noted. Take care.
Hi, Docent. I’m back to you again about the tunnel-pumps...

I’m busy right now... Ah, to hell with it! I’ll tear myself away from my work for a bit. I owe you anyway.\nWait a bit, I’ll check my notes on the laptop. All info that might be of interest to me or to those who regularly come to me, like you for example, I prefer to convert into electronic format.\nOh-ho... I don’t want to upset you, Marked One, but I have nothing useful to report on your question. Except that control of the power supply and control of the pumps themselves are carried out from different locations. And the pumping installations themselves are located somewhere in a third place altogether. Something like that...
I’m busy right now... Ah, to hell with it! I’ll tear myself away from my work for a bit. We agreed on two artifacts, right? Did you bring them?
Of course. Will these do?
Yeah... Where are they?! I was sure I put them in my backpack. Wait a bit, I’ll bring them soon...
So, what’s new around here?

What’s new... There are hardly any people left, can’t you see? Fewer and fewer every day, everyone’s heading north, and only a handful come back. Where do they all disappear to, what kind of black hole do they fall into? Have you been there yourself, or are you still just getting ready?
Hard to say... Feels like I was, and feels like I wasn’t.

Ah, right. You’re, well — not quite right in the head. You remember some things, forget others... \nBy the way, a guy stopped by here, asking about someone with an unusual tattoo on their arm. I thought of you right away. You’ve got that distinctive mark on your wrist, don’t you?
Well, yeah. So what?

And that’s it. The guy acted all important, businesslike. Talked like he was giving orders. Ask him anything — and he snaps back that it’s none of your business, while he himself just keeps asking questions.
And why would he need me?
Why you specifically? He didn’t name any names, and you yourself supposedly don’t even remember what your name is. Or have you remembered it already?
I remember everything just fine now. And I’m not sick. My name is the Marked One. I am the Marked One. Clear?
Alright, Marked One it is, marked by a sign... So, that’s who he needed — someone marked by the sign. I don’t recall a second one like that. Draw your own conclusions.
Not enough data yet to draw conclusions. Anything else?

I told him I couldn’t help, that the Zone’s full of people and every second one’s probably got something tattooed. And he replied: if someone with a strange mark does turn up, tell him they’ll be waiting for him at the Warehouses, at the bus stop on the road to the Red Forest. So I’m passing that on.
At the Warehouses... Must’ve been a mercenary, then.
Could be. Go there and find out for yourself.
Not sure I need that meeting. We’ll see how things go.
Do you know where Ghost went?
No. And I don’t want to know!
Why’s that?
That Ghost of yours is a real operator. He brought some armed gang with him that nearly trashed the place, and then vanished without a trace.
You must be mistaken. Ghost is a loner, he’s not connected to any gang.

Well, maybe he didn’t bring them, maybe they came to him — what difference does it make. They barged in, started bossing everyone around, asking about some tools for some kind of weapon, making demands, threatening... I had to put them in their place by mentioning just a few high-ranking names overseeing our work. Before that Ghost showed up, we never had this kind of bacchanalia here. I even warned Professor Vasilyev not to get involved with such shady characters. But no! And here’s the result — Vasilyev is still in a vegetative state, and thugs are storming scientific laboratories.

I don’t see a connection here. And aren’t you exaggerating? Stalkers are always wandering around here, all armed, any of them can start waving weapons if they really want something. By that logic, you could call anyone a thug.
Manners, young man. You can tell a person by their manners, weapons or no weapons. And I won’t let that Ghost of yours even set foot on my doorstep again.
Will you throw him out yourself, or assign it to a graduate student?

No need to be sarcastic. Of course, I can’t stand up to brute force, but one thing’s certain — he won’t get anything more from me. And enough about Ghost, let’s change the subject. What brings you here? Your account is still open.
I don’t need anything right now.
Semenov, can you tell me what happened here? What was all that noise, what kind of raid was it?
There was no raid at all. And no real noise either, except for Sakharov’s own screeching.
So who was it that came?

Some well-equipped types showed up. Started questioning Sakharov, barged into his office, rummaged around on the desks without any ceremony. But no shouting, all businesslike. They were looking for something specific.
So what about your security?

Very funny... Our security is good against monsters. But here — either they didn’t notice them, or didn’t want to notice, or didn’t dare. I locked myself in that little room and didn’t stick my head out. All I heard was some mumbling and movement. And Sakharov’s shouts and his “threats” to call someone.
So what does Ghost have to do with it? And what did they want?

Nothing at all! Ghost wasn’t mentioned at all. That’s just the professor imagining things, trying to find someone to blame. I didn’t open the door, heard things vaguely, and didn’t understand everything I heard. I asked Sakharov, but he didn’t understand much either. Long story short, someone told them that we might have special tools here for some kind of special weapon. That’s probably what they were looking for.
You’re issued special weapons?

You too?! No, of course not. Sakharov told them the same — that we don’t have anything like that and don’t deal with it at all, that we do biological and... well, completely different research. And they listened to him very attentively, but kept doing their thing. I could hear them moving crates behind the wall. Like the saying goes — “Vaska listens, but keeps eating.” Sakharov went on about “I’ll call, I’ll report!..” They rustled around a bit more and left. Maybe they really took in what Sakharov said, or maybe they realized there was nothing there and no point searching, and backed off.

Hmm... Someone told me about “Monolith weapons.” Could that be the special weapon in question? Supposedly it also requires a whole suitcase of tools. Still, I doubt you could hide that in a desk drawer.
Yeah... Still, it’s interesting what they could have meant. What kind of weapon, what kind of tools? Any ideas?

You listen to all sorts of fairy tales... Although Doctor Perelman once talked about some tools to grab something and place it into a sealed container. But I think he was talking about an artifact. Or maybe he was actually talking about the “Black Mark,” wanted to put it into a container.

Who knows?! Anything’s possible... For example, Doctor Perelman once talked about some tools to grab something and place it into a sealed container. But I think he was talking about an artifact. Or maybe he was actually talking about the “Black Mark,” wanted to put it into a container.
Tell me more.
There’s nothing more to tell... That’s how rumors are born and nonsense spreads across the Zone. And then someone filters those stupid rumors and starts a “treasure hunt.”
Rumors, you say? Uh-huh...
So why are you loitering here? Can’t you see — I’m thinking. Get lost, go chase dogs...
Some thinker you are...
Hey, man, what do you want?
Well, one of your guys asked me to bring him a little thing, promised mountains of gold, and then disappeared somewhere.
So he disappeared, big deal. Did you find what he needed?
I... didn’t bring it with me... stashed it for now. I actually wanted to ask him a few things. You haven’t heard that story about a suitcase of tools, have you? And about some Sniper...

Ah... so he was feeding you that mono-gun crap too? Really got on my nerves with that talk. But if you’re curious, I’ll tell you. Supposedly he met a scientist, and that one started spinning some tale about a super-duper weapon. You can’t just use it, supposedly — you need special tools. And it wasn’t about Sniper at all, but about Strelok himself... well, you get it. People will make up anything.
I see... So the tool belongs to Strelok, huh? Where did you say that scientist was, and what was his name?
Oh come on, you actually bought that? Somewhere in Yantar, I think... Others already came by asking too. But it’s all nonsense.
I’m just asking so I don’t have to listen to that nonsense again... So who was it that came?
You’re really getting on my nerves with the questions! Who, who... A horse in a coat. Took the coat off and left. You drinking? No? Then beat it, stop bothering me.
Alright, calm down... You’ve already got drinking buddies, and I’m not in the mood. Just don’t drink away your coat.
You keep poking around, poking around... No peace.
Peace will be in the grave. And even that’s not guaranteed.
